subject: Management
title: Systems Thinking
description: A micro-lesson that makes Systems Thinking usable.

hook.text: A hospital reduced ER wait times. Admissions rose. Beds filled. Discharge slowed. Waits got worse again.

buildup.text: Organizations are systems. Changing one part creates ripple effects throughout the whole.

discovery.text: Peter Senge: systems thinking sees the whole pattern, not just individual events or symptoms.

twist.text: The obvious fix often makes things worse. Systems fight back through feedback loops and delays.

climax.text: Map the system before intervening. Look for feedback loops, delays, and unintended consequences.

punchline.text: Fix the system, not the symptom. Or the symptom keeps returning.

quiz.question: Why is systems thinking important for strategy?
options: Changing one part creates ripple effects that can make the whole system worse
Systems always respond positively to direct interventions
Individual events matter more than underlying patterns
